note.p: Ridgley C. Powers served as governor of Mississippi from 1871 to 1874.

Born in Mecca, Ohio, on December 24, 1836, Powers was raised and educated in the north. In 1862, after receiving a degree from the University of Michigan, and conducting graduate work at Union College in New York, Powers enlisted in the Union Army for service during the Civil War. He was promoted to second lieutenant and then captain in the 125th Ohio Infantry Regiment and saw action in Tennessee and Georgia. By the time the Civil War ended in 1865, Powers had achieved the rank of colonel.

Upon separating from the military, Powers settled in Mississippi. He purchased land and began a cotton plantation. He soon became a public figure, serving as sheriff in Noxubee County. By 1868, Powers had gained status in Mississippi’s Republican Party, and was elected lieutenant governor in 1869. Although he was a “carpet bagger” (northerner who settled in the south during Reconstruction), Powers was generally respected by white Mississippians. This was in contrast to Governor James Alcorn, a northern by birth, but who was considered a “scalawag” since he had lived in Mississippi since the 1840s and had served in the Confederacy before joining the Republican Party. When Alcorn resigned the governor’s office in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate, Powers assumed the state’s executive office. He became active in promoting Mississippi’s economic development and independence, advocating crop variety and lesser dependence upon imported goods. Despite his efforts to maintain a stable political and economic environment in Mississippi, a rift grew among Republicans that led to competing party nominations for governor in 1873. Alcorn was nominated by the more conservative wing of Republicans against Adelbert Ames, former Union general and military governor, who was backed by the radicals. Ames won the election and took the governor’s seat in 1874.

In 1875, shortly after leaving office, Powers married Louisa Born. The couple had one child who died in infancy. They moved to Arizona, but Louisa suffered from a mysterious medical condition and began traveling across the United States and Europe for treatment. She passed away in New York in 1882 after undergoing surgery. Powers later remarried (to Mary Wilson) and moved to California. He spent the rest of his life as a rancher and businessman at Los Angeles. He died on November 11, 1912, and is buried in Angelus Rosedale Cemetery in Los Angeles, California.

The Province of New York was established 1664. Admitted as the 11th state, New York achieved statehood July 26, 1788. (Wikipedia)
The Republic of Texas was established on March 2, 1836. Admitted as the 28th state, Texas achieved statehood December 29, 1845. (Wikipedia)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
The Territory of Louisiana was established on July 4, 1805. Admitted as the 18th state, Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. (Britannica; Wikipedia)

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to discover information about crimes and find out who is responsible for them." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi judiciary was established by Article 6 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890. It is one of three branches of the Mississippi state government, along with the executive branch and the legislative branch. The judiciary branch is composed of four tiers of court: limited jurisdiction, general jurisdiction, intermediate appellate, and last resort. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Treasurer's office was created in 1817 in Jackson when the state was admitted to the Union. The State Legislature appointed the State Treasurer until 1832 when the Treasurer became popularly elected to serve a two-year term (changed to four years in 1869). The State Treasurer is responsible for overseeing and maintaining Mississippi's financial records. (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

div.p: 1st
To The Honorable The Members of The 4/10/73 Legislature of The State of Mississippi
Your Memorialist Shows that She has rendered to this State important services which entitles her to the following rewards asked for in Senate Bill No 158.1/2
"For the Capture of C S Swann
$1000.,, "For Special detectives Whitley & Fitzpatrick. $500,, And Sets forth the following charge reasons for Such claim,,

That on the 9th of Octr /72 She was employed in behalf of this State by C S Bell. to assist him in ascertaining the whereabouts of Dr C S Swann. or to obtain if possible such infor-mation as Should lead to his apprehension and arrest. Also to aid him in certain enqui-ries and investigations respecting a number of forged and fraudalent Mississippi State Warrants, the existence of which having become known was Seriously threatening the States credit—That this C S Bell repr-esenting himself as a commisioned officer of this State and Celing Private Secretary of Gov Powers. Claimed that by virtue of his office and by direct comand of his Excell-ency he was empowered and authorised to offer the following inducements
2nd
1st that for any advise or information which should lead to the apprehension and arrest of Dr C S Swann. She Should recieve a reward of five hundred dollars $500. to be paid immediately on his arrest

2nd Should She be able to learn from whom one Wm F Dunham had received a number of those fraudalent warrants. And by such information or other assistance, Should be able to aid this State in defeating the attempted fraud upon her credit, that Gov Powers would recommend this Legislature at its next convening to grant an appropriation of reward to recompense Such Service

3rd That for the recovery of the whole or any amount of those fraudulent warrants. Gov Powers in his own and in behalf of the State guranteed to the person recovering them from the parties then having them in posession a liberal private recompense
4th That all nescessary travelling and incidental expences incurred by her during Such em-ploy should be advanced and borne by the State
5th That Such Services in whole or in part proving Successful. She was to remain in the permanent employ of this State as an assistant Special Agent or detective under
3nd

the direction of C S Bell at a Salary of one hundred dollars $100 per Month, reckoning from date. And to recieve in addition to Such Salary one half of all rewards which by thier joint efforts should be obtained for the apprehension and arrest of Criminals

That to the faithful observance of those conditions and promises C S Bell pledged not only his own honor as an officer of this State—but also that of its Chief Magistrate Gov Powers whom he claimed to have the authority to represent

Your Memorialist further desires to Show That relying on those promises She devoted herself exclusively to the pursuit of every honest and Legitimate Means by which the desired information and result might be obtained. And that assisted therin by Wm F Dunham she was successful in ascertaining
1st The alias, and recent movements of Dr C S Swann
2nd The names of the parties from whom ?? Wm F Dunham had recieved a number of the fraudulent State warrants
3rd The amount of fraudulent warrants then known to be in existence
4th Where those warrants were then placed
4th

5th That She recovered Forty Thousand dollars $40.000 of those warants which She immediately placed in the hands of C S Bell who as agent for the State claim-ed the right in behalf of the State to recieve them=
6th That She Succeeded in getting a list of the original members of the raised and fraudulent warrants not yet recovered which She also placed in the hands of C S Bell

7th That by the aid of a certain letter and private information which She conveyed to C S Bell. He accompanied and personally assisted by her Succeeded in ascertaining the abode of Dr C S Swann and in this information immediately effected his arrest.

In view of those facts as set forth and many more of vast importance which She is prepared to address before any proper tribunal. Your Memorialist comes before this body representing alike the interests and honor of this State. And prays that a full and impartial investigation be had before this honorable body as to her merits in having rendered valuable Services to this State—And farther prays
5th

that in consideration of Such Services as She Shall estblish having rendered that the rewards as a bove Specified in Senate Bill No 158.1/2 may be assigned to her instead of to the Several parties now claiming them. And for the welfare of this State and honorable body your Memorialist will ever pray (For corroboration an affidavit of Wm F Dunham
Signed hereto annexed, and letters of
For amount of monies recieved from C S Bell on behalf of the State and the purposes to which Such Monies were appli-ed See Exhibit A & B hereto annexed

Hinds County } Personally appeared before the undersigned Clerk of the Supreme Court Mary J McBride who being first duly sworn deposeth and says that the statements contained at the above memorial are true.

Subscribed and Sworn } Mary Jane McBride

Memorial of Mary
Jane McBride

Ways & Means
March 26/73
[seal]

Jackson Miss.
April 10th 1873

To Whom it may Concern: I the undersigned Wm F. Dunham a citizen of the State of Louisiana and a resident of the City of New Orleans, do hereby certify the fol-lowing to be a true and correct statement of the Miss Mary J. McBride's connection with the working up of the Mississippi Warrant Forgery case; [?]: That in the month of October /72 Miss McBride after several interviews final-ly persuaded me to see Mr Bell which I did on Monday Oct. 14th when on my enquiring of Mr Bell his authority, he represented himself to be special agent of the State and Governor Powers' Acting Private Secretary. And pledged his, the State's and Governor's honor that whatever promises were made by him Should be strictly carried out. He said no one concerned in the matter except the Chief Forger Should be troubled in any way as the State of Mississippi did not wish to go to the expense of prosecuting any Save the principal perpetrator: That he had employ-ed Miss McBride in behalf of the State at a Salary of $100. per. mo. and her travelling expenses paid: That a certain C. S. Swan was supposed to be the principal forger and Should he be arrest-ed through any information given by Miss McBride She Should immediately receive a reward of $500.:

that Miss McBride should proceed to New York where I should obtain the warrants and hand them to her as the duly authorized agent of the State. That for the recovery of these war-rants the Governor would not only pay a re-ward out of his own pocket but would recom-mend the Legislature at its next session to ap-propriate a sum of money which as the State was liberal in these matters would not be less than $5000 of which she should receive one half. On my telling Mr Bell that Miss Mc-Bride was some time persuading me to inter-view him as I intended to leave for New York, obtain the warrants and return them to the party who gave them to me, he answered Miss McBride had acted nobly and he would guarantee the State would duly appreciate her services. This closed the interview A short time after having learned that a Dr Woodward who had taken me off the Steam Ship "S" Louis at Quarantine was the C. S. Swann aforementioned which information and his whereabouts I immediately conveyed to Miss McBride. In pursuance of the agreement between myself and Bell on my arrival in New York. I turned over $40,000 of warrants to Miss McBride the balance having been ordered to Texas during my absence and it was agreed between myself and Miss Mc Bride that I should remain in New York, endea—

—vor to trace the missing warrants and should I learn anything in regard to them notify her immediately. I will here state that had it not been for the interposition of a Col. Whitley and his men in all probability the State would now be in possession of them.—This I did from time to time and Mr Bell has since acknowled-ged having received it. Miss McBride never warned me in N.Y. quarantine or elsewhere of any danger to me but on the contrary all of her letters showed the utmost anxiety for the reco-very of the warrants and the arrest of Dr Swann and had it not been for her the State of Mis-sissippi would certainly, never have recovered one warrant or learned the names of the ^guilty^ parties.

Having heard lately that C.S. Bell has said Miss McBride knew the character of the $300
warrant when I gave it to her in New Orleans I will state that it is not so, as at my first inter-vivew with him and several times since I have distinctly told him; and refused to swear she did when summoned before the Grand Jury of Hinds Coin Jan—4 last, although he attempted to compel me to swear to it by intimidation and bribery.

Hinds County
State of Mississippi
Personally came and appeared before me the undersigned clerk of the Supreme Court of Mississippi W.F. Dunham who makes both that the allegations set forth in the witheld statement are true

Subscribed & Sworn to
this 10 April AD 1873 } W. F. Dunham
Jas M McKee
Clerk
